answers.text: size of the air-gap area and the back-iron depth

qas.question: What three elements determine the size of the air-gap area and back iron depth?

answers.text: power rating of the armature winding set, the speed of the machine, and the achievable air-gap flux density before core saturation

qas.question: What does continuous torque density refer to?

answers.text: method of cooling and permissible period of operation before destruction by overheating

qas.question: How does continuous torque density vary between well designed motors?

plausible_answers.text: size of the air-gap area and the back-iron depth,
achievable air-gap flux density before core saturation

qas.question: What is the fourth element that determines the size of the air-gap area and back iron depth?

plausible_answers.text: method of cooling and permissible period of operation before destruction by overheating

qas.question: What doesn't continuous torque density refer to?
How does non-continuous torque density vary between well designed motors?

context: The continuous torque density of conventional electric machines is determined by the <a0_0><b4_0>size of the air-gap area and the back-iron depth<a0_0/>,<b4_0/> which are determined by the <a1_0>power rating of the armature winding set, the speed of the machine, and the <b5_0>achievable air-gap flux density before core saturation<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Despite the high coercivity of neodymium or samarium-cobalt PMs, continuous torque density is <a3_0><b7_0>virtually the same<b7_0/><a3_0/> amongst electric machines with optimally designed armature winding sets. Continuous torque density relates to <a2_0><b6_0>method of cooling and permissible period of operation before destruction by overheating<b6_0/><a2_0/> of windings or PM damage.
